data.title: Fixed SimpleAudioEngine may cause application to crash on Android L(5.0.x)
Camera::project(const Vec3& src) method return the wrong Vec2::y value
data.body:
cocos2d-x version is 3.6.
When i set the xoz as the ground,i found that the Camera::project(const Vec3& src) method returned a reverse Vec2::y value.

For example the Camera::LookAt(Vec3(0,0,0)) and the postion of the 3D node in the 3D world is (0,0,-400)(display on the top of the screen),so, the Camera::project(const Vec3& src) should return a Vec2::y that on the top of the screen( for example 800),but in fact,this method return a value that on the bottom of the screen( for example 50).

This version is planned to only "fix existing bugs" and "unfinished tasks".
We need to improve the quality after a 3D rush in v3.6 and v3.7.

data.body:
Implementation of feature request #10415

Contains all changes done in cocos2d#10530, with minor changes to make it work on the current v3 branch.

Tested Win32: cpp-tests, js-tests and lua-tests (On Windows 8.1)
Tested Android: cpp-tests, js-tests and lua-tests (On Android 5.1.1)

Discussion thread can be found [here](http://discuss.cocos2d-x.org/t/vibrate-requirement-collection/20207).

data.title: Label with outline crash on winRT
data.body:
I've found a bug playing with Labels, it only occurs on winRT (fine in iOS/Mac/Win32/Android).
It's only for specific glyphs, and specific fonts, and always when outline is enabled.

An example of such a crash can be make easily.
Create a new project using the cocos console (from cocos 3.3 up to current v4-develop version), and change the Label creation from HelloWorldScene.cpp to this:

auto label = Label::createWithTTF("e", std::string("fonts/intuitive.ttf"), 70);
label->enableOutline(Color4B::BLACK, 2);

Get the intuitive.ttf font here: https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B1_hJ_Q8mPOBcUVRTVRXUk96ZlE

Compile and run on a windows 8.1 computer using the win32-debug target of the win8.1-universal project.
As soon as the label is rendered, it crashs.
Not sure if it has an effect, but my desktop screen resolution is 1920*1080.

Thanks

data.title: Request: add 'enable cascade color' option in CocosStudio
data.body:
There is no any option available in CocosStudio which is equivalent of `Node::setCascadeColorEnabled(bool cascadeColorEnabled)` method in runtime.

data.title: V3.7 winrt audio fix
data.body: This pull request fixes a freezing crash in Windows 10 with the new audio engine when pressing stop after play. This fixes issue https://github.com/MSOpenTech/cocos2d-x/issues/160

data.title: fbx-conv "loses" clamping on materials
data.body:
Fbx-conv has a bug where we seem to "lose" whether a file has clamping on its textures or not. A working .obj file with clamping set to true for materials will have wrapModeU and wrapModeV set to REPEAT in the converted c3t file (and corresponding c3b) instead of "CLAMP".

If needed, send me an email and I can send an example material and obj file.

data.title: Remove unneeded include files and fixed warns.
WinRT: PreloadSoundEffect search path error
data.body:
Hi,

on winRT (checked from cocos3.3 to 3.6), there is a bug in the PreloadSoundEffect function that prevent it from find the sound resource if using FileUtils searchPaths.

My resources folder looks like this:
Resources/common
Resources/lowres
Resources/highres

In common, I store all resolution-independant files, and lowres/highres speaks for themselves.
During game init, I setup my search paths using FileUtils::getInstance()->setSearchPaths(searchPath);
I always add "common", then add either lowres or highres.

Problem is (winRT only, works fine on iOS/MacOS/Android/Win32), the PreloadSoundEffect function of winRT does not use the FileUtils searchpaths, it's only looking inside the base "Resources" folder.
(I try to load "sfx/effect.wav", on other platforms it correctly find it in "Resources/common/sfx/effect.wav" but on winRT it only search in "Resources/sfx/effect.wav").

data.title: Refactor Web engine's core to modules
data.body:
The web engine is now managed by a dependency config file (moduleConfig.json) and a poor script insertion mechanism. AMD/CMD module management will be great for the web engine to manage module dependencies. 
## Essential benefits
1. User and the engine itself can profit from module management feature.
2. It can help user to build up their own web workflow and easily combine cocos with other frameworks.
3. The granularity of modules can be greatly reduced, the result is that a web package can be very small.
4. Avoid global variable pollution, reduce variables in some namespaces.
## Proposed solution
- [ ] Choose between require.js or CMD solution (like sea.js). AMD is more web friendly with asynchronous feature, but CMD have more compact API and usage.
- [ ] Create a tool based on gulp or `r.js` directly to package all js files into one file and obfuscate the js file.
- [ ] Refactor CCBoot.js to support two ways of dependency management (The old one and the new one).
- [ ] Keep compatibility with old versions.
- [ ] Refactor engine's core module with the new module management system.
## IMPORTANT

SHOULDN'T AFFECT API
